type="html">;当我在早上通勤路上开始阅读台北时，我想知道我是不是在晚上被切除了脑叶。在回家的路上，我想知道为什么一个讨厌文字的人会不厌其烦地排成一排。第二天早上，我想知道，他为什么恨我？就像人们对操场恶霸或恐怖分子的疑惑一样。为什么他要把他的“框架式的东西”、他的“土壤式的区域”、“他的墨西哥卷饼的沙拉式残留物”强加给我？他为什么要夺走我的喜乐？当我在邮件中收到这本小说时，我不明白陶林是我以前见过的名字，在几个互联网前的朦胧时期，当我学习脂肪接受和特雷西伊根莫里西仍然被称为荡妇机器时。后来，我认出这个名字是在未读的 Gawker 头条新闻（结果是未读的百万篇文章）中观察到的东西。我报此，是要让你知道，我初读台北时，厌恶之心是纯粹的。小说开篇，我们跟随一位名叫保罗的作家在布鲁克林四处游荡，等待他的新书之旅开始。我们和他在一起，因为他有点经历分手，有点参加聚会，有点“做事”（有时在引号中，有时不），肯定会购买少量杂货，好像是为了产生最大的烦恼（ “有机牛肉饼、两个康普茶、五个香蕉、紫花苜蓿芽、芝麻菜、大麻籽油、一个红洋葱、生姜”），绝对可以消磨与伪朋友尴尬交流的时间马特慢慢地制作鳄梨酱”），这肯定让他妈妈很不高兴。保罗注意到劳拉正在看着他的那堆建筑用纸，并说如果她想要的话，她可以要一些，她不自觉地专注于想要一些，说她会如何使用它以及她喜欢什么颜色，以一种做作的真诚方式表现出感激——一个不相信自己的自然行为会显得真诚的人的真诚……几分钟后，劳拉离开了，温顺地拿着她的手鼓、摇壶和一些建筑用纸。 “我看到你‘参与’了施工纸，”保罗用他们见面那天晚上用来推荐 Funyuns 的讽刺、戏谑的声音说道，但表情严肃。 “就颜色而言，这是不错的选择。好工作。” “你说过我可以吃一些，”劳拉犹豫地说。每个人的年龄都被记录下来，就像在时髦的警察记事簿中一样：“23 岁的露西向保罗和米奇介绍了自己和 23 岁的艾米以及 25 岁的丹尼尔，并介绍了她和艾米的在线杂志。”我说这位小说家讨厌文字，因为这部小说读起来好像是一场不正当的竞赛强加的严格参数的结果，或者某种虚无主义哲学的法令，尽可能少使用有趣的文字。陶林似乎渴望一种我只能用“无情”来形容的散文。当需要形容词时，有时不需要时，Lin 通常会在名词后加上“y”（参见：“soil-y”）。一些传统形式的形容词和副词用引号括起来；我相信要传达这本书的首要主题，即保罗的大部分观察力都集中在业务上，而不是像内省那样研究的东西，而是从外部优势进行长时间的自我注视。他的引号策略达到了这种效果，但它也传达了对单词及其代表或含义的尴尬。他把手伸到毯子外面，“暗暗地”拉着他的 MacBook，他觉得，就像章鱼一样拉向自己。现在是凌晨 12 点 52 分，距离离开 Angelica Kitchen 已近三个小时。令保罗惊讶的是，劳拉 (Laura) 发了两次电子邮件——一些句子片段在晚上 11 点 43 分为她的尴尬表示歉意，保罗在上午 12 点 05 分的一段详细说明他理解并喜欢她，认为她“很酷”。几分钟后她回应了，看起来很高兴。再发几封电子邮件后，她似乎几乎“头晕目眩”。他们承诺——认真而热情，保罗觉得——明天一起去纹身。如果林太顽固而不能使用从安全引号中剥离出来的“giddy”这个词，他会不遗余力地使用许多不起眼的词来传达他的角色的感受。这些无聊的句子通过它们的长度和逗号的数量与其他无聊的说明性句子区分开来，这使小说充满了一种节奏失常，不知何故也成功地变得单调：他把自己的轨迹想象成一个真空密封的管子，他d 到达并通过它——在他自己生活的真空密封管中独自旅行——他将被吸走并从中退出，作为对一些难以想象的接受者的成功交付。其他的叙述选择表明要么是根本懒惰，无法找到有趣的词语组合来描述事物，要么是齐心协力使用最少的“文学”修饰来描述保罗的世界（这两种可能性在传达洞察力或审美方面达到了相同的目的）读者的乐趣）。即使是列出年龄的自负似乎也像是一种粗心的速记，用来描述人们而不是真正描述他们，尽管这种策略在小说的后面方便地揭示了保罗的作者粉丝群都比他年轻（有时这样不恰当：例如，“卡尔文，18 岁, 和 Maggie，17 岁，高三学生，”Paul 和他的女朋友 Erin 与他们一起吸毒并在 Calvin 在俄亥俄州的“豪宅”的热水浴缸里游泳——原文引号——在俄亥俄州）。在最初对这部小说产生深深的、焦虑的厌恶之后，一种不情愿的欣赏萌生了。保罗在小说中的吸毒开始于在我看来你的父母不喜欢它但不要拨打求助热线的使用 - 这里的 Ambien，那里的 Adderall，Xanax。然而，最终，保罗和他的朋友们开始持续吸毒。当毒品开始流行时（MDMA、LSD、蘑菇、海洛因、Xanax、Klonopin、可卡因、羟考酮、美沙酮），我认为这本小说开始为它的可怕找借口，即因为它现在有一个我可以识别的问题。这些角色似乎注定要情绪或身体崩溃，这立即让他们变得更有趣。 “无动于衷”也是有道理的；如果你写的是一个通常处于一团糟的抑郁症患者的观察，那么形容词可能是第一个被淘汰的。你的角色也会发表很多完全愚蠢的言论，就像这里的玛姬，在卡尔文父母的游泳池里吃蘑菇游泳时：“如果我们现在都肥胖怎么办？”这种对话以极其准确的方式传达，代表了本书的一些“最佳”部分。在保罗和艾琳做出在拉斯维加斯结婚的惊人选择之后（“‘我一点也不明白，’保罗说。‘人们就是这么做的。这就是人们想要的。’这看起来真的很疯狂， ’保罗说。”），他们一起在布鲁克林闲逛，开始了一个令人遗憾的“蜜月”，去台北看保罗的父母，并服用了一些我认为会使你的神经系统崩溃和/或促使你父母兴奋的药物（或某人）报警。他们感受到了药物的作用，并在台北快餐店周围走得更远，为自己在 YouTube 上的一系列关于吸毒的视频录制自己的视频。在整个逗留期间，他们表现出一种因毒品和虚荣心而增强的诚实，但这种诚实并不完全是诚实，这与我认为维持人际关系所必需的慷慨和热情恰恰相反。我开始认为这可能是一部悲伤的小说——因为毒品，这个已经被类固醇肌肉自我意识麻痹的家伙正在浪费他的生命，用他彻头彻尾的胡言乱语惊动了台北的快餐店员工，伤了他父母的心，在他做的时候烦死了我。但是，就像小说中其他有希望的问题一样——比如保罗与家人、女孩、朋友、自我、工作的关系，或者他在全食超市花费的时间——小说拒绝将他的吸毒病态化，尽管这是一种经过时间考验的吸引读者的方式。说到空洞的言论，阅读台北几乎是让我哑口无言的任何事情。当我在别人能听到的范围内说话时，尤其是比我年长的人，我突然开始听到自己的声音。在 BART 平台上，我听到自己说“这就像，不是我计划发生的事情，”我的声音拖得很长当我开始意识到自己口语表达的贫乏时，我有时听起来一定很像台北人（“‘我觉得我毫不讽刺地认为这是一个重大的考验，’卡尔文说。”）我出生了陶琳次年；听到我们共同的成语从我嘴里说出来，我意识到我对这本书的一些厌恶是非常个人化的。对我最想从我的自我表现和自我中清除的那些东西有一种可怕的认识。这一认识，让陶林心中又生出一丝微弱的敬意。首先，我测试了他在嘲笑我们所有的低能和表达方式的想法，但拒绝了它是错误的，因为我无法想象一个担任文化评论家角色的人能够忍受记录所有这些遭遇，除非他是能够服用大量的 Xanax 但不记得这样做了，这是我管理飞机的方式（我想这不是完全不可能的）。接下来，我认为这位作者可能做出了一个激进的、因此是赞美的承诺，即捕捉事物的本来面目或在他看来，无论他们在页面上看起来多么令人震惊或无聊（可能因为他们这样做）：劳拉称赞Paul 的头发和“随意”的程度，然后，部分走到桌子底下，向 Paul 的鞋子举起蜡烛——从 Paul 在桌子上方的角度来看，鞋子感觉是固定的，并且像鞋盒一样用于存储——询问它们是什么品牌。陶林会不会是……羞耻后？，我想知道。菲利普·拉金突然想到，“高窗：”“当我看到几个孩子/猜他在操她，而她/正在吃药或戴着隔膜，/我知道这是天堂”）。然而，这种联想实际上也是让我最终拒绝这个假设的原因：陶林可能会随意录制一些让我感到羞辱的东西，即听起来像个白痴，但他的性别是杜鲁门秀的性别。当内裤脱下时，从叙述的角度来说，摄像机礼貌地移开视线。我们所听到的只是它的发生、它的位置和持续时间。人们可能会将此视为另一种形式的文化或个人批评：对于非常关注自我和自我感受以及自我服用多少药物的人来说，性是人类最先放弃的正常优先事项之一。但后来我们读到了艾琳和保罗在台北的一段对话，当时他们互相征求意见并“批评”他们的实力。虽然保罗说性对他来说不是“那么大的事情”，但艾琳仍然向他和我们保证，他“擅长一切”并且“[保持]有趣”并且她“[有]性高潮......经常”从激进的人类经验目录中来对待性，感觉是一种贫乏、懦弱的方式。回到那里，我觉得有必要提及我厌恶的最初纯洁性，因为在谷歌搜索、点亮新链接和长期黑暗的链接之后，厌恶很快就会被外界影响玷污和放大。我什至从马口中发现了对我对陶林比较仁慈的拒绝：《娱乐周刊》问：“你在写这本书的时候，就预料到这会是你的‘代表作’。”成功了吗？ ”陶琳回答说：“是的，因为我没有为将来的书存钱。直到我生命中的这一点，我都使用了我所知道或感受到或经历过的一切，或者可以想象知道、感受或经历过的一切作为原始资料。” Then at Thought Catalog, I was treated to a first-hand account of “What It's Like To Be In a Tao Lin Novel“: I've always wondered what it was like for people friendly with, like, Hemingway and whatnot. These authors, like Tao, write pretty closely to their personal experience… I will treasure this book for the rest of my life not because my friend wrote it, or because it's the best book ever written (goddamn is it good, though), or because I'm in it and so are a lot of other people I care about, but actually because of a scene I'm not even in. Six simple lines of dialogue. –“You said you only go to like one party a month. But you're at almost every party,” [said Daniel]. “This isn't normal at all,” said Paul. “Before we met I probably did less than one thing a month.” “You, Mitch, Laura… Amy,” said Paul. “I'm going to the bathroom.”– (I don't mind airing my loathing, because Tao Lin seems like he can take it. In Taipei, he anticipates it: “He read an account of his Toronto reading, when he'd been sober, describing him as 'monosyllabic,' 'awkward,' 'stilted and unfriendly' within a disapproval of his oeuvre, itself vaguely within a disapproval of contemporary culture and, by way of a link to someone else's essay, the internet.”) My loathing was never pure, of course.并不真地。 I think that really great writing is bracing, and makes you feel like making something of your own, either another piece of writing, or a joyful noise unto the Lord. Then there are things you read, a little less great, that don't make you feel one way or another, creatively speaking. Then there is a small, deadly class of book that make you never want to set pen to paper again. Tao Lin's novel is a grave case of this latter kind, where you are faced with the consequences of writing down all the things you do or think. What if they sound like this? Colorless, witless, humorless. Picking out individual passages cannot express their cumulative monotonous assault on the senses. The good thing about Taipei, if you're like me, is that its characters will make you want to hug your lover, have a baby, go to work, call your mom. But maybe you'll rethink that novel, that personal essay. In the cold ruthless scheme of things, that might not be such a bad thing. But it makes me look upon this novel as dangerous and threatening to life, like as the anti-choicer looks upon the abortionist. Last week I participated in an online survey about ethics in book reviewing. One of the questions asked something like, “Is it okay to review the book of someone to whom you are aesthetically or philosophically opposed,” and I think I answered “Yes,” although I think the correct answer is “No,” or possibly “I'm not sure.” The next day, I saw (on Twitter) an assertion by no less a person than Joyce Carol Oates that reviews should include a minimum of opinion. I am not sure what all of this means for my ethics or my prospects as a book reviewer. But I'll say it: It is my opinion that this novel is awful, and I am aesthetically or philosophically opposed to it. Likely it comes from some hypocrite-lecteur-mon-semblable-mon-frere place, but Taipei brought out all of my conservative instincts. Only a real codger would say this, but if this is the output we can expect from one of our bright young things, we're fucked. I've decided to reinvent The Millions. The blog world is crowded. I cannot possibly add to or improve upon the innumerable blogs out there that are about music or politics. So many of the things that I have a casual interest in are covered so obsessively in the blog world that it is hard to find something to write about in any sort of compelling way. Nor do I have much interest in cataloging my daily life. I know from experience that my life is capable of producing, tops, a paragraph or two of mildly amusing reading every few weeks, which does not a blog make. Plus, I would like to try to lure some people into reading what I write, and writing about what I ate for lunch today will likely not do the trick. As for the two of you (you know who you are) who read this blog regularly, I hope you will not be disappointed by my change away from that format. And finally, after some thinking, I have figured out what these changes will be. The Millions will be about books. For a book lover without a whole lot of free time (not to mention money) it can be very hard to consistantly find new and interesting books. To do so, in my experience, requires reading dozens of book reviews weekly and trolling book stores looking for the new and interesting (or the old and interesting). The internet improves this process slightly, mainly by cutting out some of the time required, but it offers little help in locating a book that you might like to take a look at. I have yet to find anyone that has had much luck with Amazon's recommendations. I recently realized, though, that I am singularly qualified to write a blog about books. I work in a great little book store and therefore, in pursuit of my paycheck, I see with my own eyes the hundreds of books that come out weekly and I read reviews in dozens of newspapers and magazines. Finally, I have always loved books and I have always loved telling people about books, and now I have myself a little blog that can serve both of these loves. I hope to update several times a week, if not daily, and hopefully this thing will be chock full of interesting books at all times. They suggest that the key to productivity is not to try to multitask, but to focus on one thing at a time and make a slightly better decision about what to do next. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#list-one-task-do-it-cross-it-out" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36253882" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;The computer graphics industry got started at the university of Utah</stitle>; <id>;https://spectrum.ieee.org/history-of-computer-graphics-industry</id>; <updated>;2023-06-10T08:02:57.218842Z</updated>; <link href="https://spectrum.ieee.org/history-of-computer-graphics-industry"/>; <author>; <name>;sohkamyung</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=sohkamyung</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://spectrum.ieee.org/media-library/a-large-group-of-older-men-standing-for-a-group-portrait-some-sitting-on-chairs-in-front-and-others-standing-behind-them.jpg?id=34017358&width=1200&height=900" style="width: 220px; height: 165px;" />;<br />;The computer graphics industry owes much of its development to the pioneering work of David Evans and Ivan E. Sutherland, who conducted groundbreaking research at the University of Utah in the 1960s and '70s. Their work helped to jump-start the industry, which now relies heavily on computer graphics and visualization techniques to create popular movies and TV shows. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#the-computer-graphics-industry-got-started-at-the-university-of-utah" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36264744" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;Play (1) Linux manual page</stitle>; <id>;https://linux.die.net/man/1/play</id>; <updated>;2023-06-11T01:02:57.219193Z</updated>; <link href="https://linux.die.net/man/1/play"/>; <author>; <name>;brudgers</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=brudgers</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://linux.die.net/style/logo.svg" style="width: 220px; height: 220px;" />;<br />;SoX is a command-line audio processing tool that can read and write audio files in most popular formats, apply effects, combine multiple input sources, synthesise audio, and act as a general purpose audio player or a multi-track audio recorder. It also has limited ability to split the input into multiple output files. SoX is particularly suited to making quick, simple edits and to batch processing. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#play-1-linux-manual-page" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36256931" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;New York City will charge drivers going downtown</stitle>; <id>;https://www.cnn.com/2023/06/10/business/congestion-pricing-new-york-city-transportation/index.html</id>; <updated>;2023-06-10T15:02:57.219540Z</updated>; <link href="https://www.cnn.com/2023/06/10/business/congestion-pricing-new-york-city-transportation/index.html"/>; <author>; <name>;rntn</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=rntn</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/230530162322-04-congestion-pricing-new-york-city-restricted.jpg?c=16x9&q=h_720,w_1280,c_fill" style="width: 220px; height: 147px;" />;<br />;President Joe Biden's administration is allowing New York City to implement a toll program called "congestion pricing" that charges drivers to enter Lower Manhattan, with proposals ranging from $9 to $23 during peak hours. The toll is designed to reduce congestion, improve public transit, and generate revenue to fund $15 billion in future investments to modernize the city's public transit system. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#new-york-city-will-charge-drivers-going-downtown" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36270597" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;What is Technicolor? (2021)</stitle>; <id>;https://www.studiobinder.com/blog/what-is-technicolor-definition/</id>; <updated>;2023-06-10T19:02:57.219888Z</updated>; <link href="https://www.studiobinder.com/blog/what-is-technicolor-definition/"/>; <author>; <name>;thunderbong</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=thunderbong</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://s.studiobinder.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/What-is-Technicolor-StudioBinder.jpg" style="width: 220px; height: 124px;" />;<br />;Technicolor is a series of processes used to produce color in motion pictures, which was developed in the early 20th century and went through several iterations before settling on a three-color process. Technicolor films are known for their bright, bold, saturated colors and were widely used in Hollywood during the 1940s. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#what-is-technicolor-2021" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36254776" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;DeArrow: Crowdsourcing better titles and thumbnails on YouTube</stitle>; <id>;https://github.com/ajayyy/DeArrow</id>; <updated>;2023-06-10T20:02:57.220235Z</updated>; <link href="https://github.com/ajayyy/DeArrow"/>; <author>; <name>;tech234a</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=tech234a</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ajayyy/DeArrow/master/public/icons/logo-128.png" style="width: 220px; height: 220px;" />;<br />;The DeArrow browser extension allows users to crowdsource better titles and thumbnails for YouTube videos. Users can submit and vote on titles and screenshots from specific timestamps in the video, and the extension can generate thumbnails locally or through a thumbnail generation service. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#dearrow-crowdsourcing-better-titles-and-thumbnails-on-youtube" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36273890" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;Inside the Wuhan lab weeks before Covid</stitle>; <id>;https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/inside-wuhan-lab-covid-pandemic-china-america-qhjwwwvm0</id>; <updated>;2023-06-11T02:02:57.220585Z</updated>; <link href="https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/inside-wuhan-lab-covid-pandemic-china-america-qhjwwwvm0"/>; <author>; <name>;ricksunny</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=ricksunny</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;<img src="https://www.thetimes.co.uk/imageserver/image/%2Fmethode%2Fsundaytimes%2Fprod%2Fweb%2Fbin%2F5aedcbf4-06ec-11ee-a1e5-6222cf71d60e.jpg?crop=1575%2C886%2C0%2C0&resize=360" style="width: 220px; height: 124px;" />;<br />;Scientists in Wuhan, China were conducting dangerous experiments combining deadly coronaviruses to create a new mutant virus just as the Covid-19 pandemic began. The experiments were allegedly being funded by the Chinese military and kept secret from the public. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#inside-the-wuhan-lab-weeks-before-covid" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36276268" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; <entry xml:base="https://hackernews.betacat.io/feed.xml">; <title type="text">;Django Views – The Right Way</stitle>; <id>;https://spookylukey.github.io/django-views-the-right-way/index.html</id>; <updated>;2023-06-10T20:02:57.220934Z</updated>; <link href="https://spookylukey.github.io/django-views-the-right-way/index.html"/>; <author>; <name>;sgt</name>; <uri>;https://news.ycombinator.com/user?id=sgt</uri>; </author>; <content type="html">;The article is a guide to using Function Based Views (FBVs) in Django, as opposed to Class Based Views (CBVs), which have become the default way to teach and learn Django views in some circles. The author aims to provide transferable knowledge and cover common tasks and patterns in FBVs for which CBVs are often suggested as the solution. <a href="https://hackernews.betacat.io/#django-views-the-right-way" target="_blank">;[summary]</a>; <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36273892" target="_blank">;[comments]</a>;</content>; </entry>; </feed>;
